newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia's Crown casino opens to mixed reviews.
newsitem.headline: Australia's Crown casino opens to mixed reviews.

text.p: Australia's Crown casino, the largest in Asia, rolled out the red carpet for a star-studded guest-list at its opening on Thursday, throwing the spotlight on a fierce debate over the nation's embrace of gambling.
Performers from around the world, including singers Billy Joel, Elton John and Ray Charles, were flown in for the event, the highlight of which was an extravagant fireworks display.

The Melbourne casino, the cost of which has been put by some analysts at over A$2 billion (US$1.56 billion), aims to deprive unlucky punters of more than A$1 billion in its first year, most of it from Asian high rollers.

In a clear sign Crown wants to lure the region's heaviest gamblers, Crown Ltd's founder and chairman, Lloyd Williams, fed a lettuce to a Chinese "dragon" during a good-luck ceremony. Crown has said that the focus is Asia in terms of international revenue.
"I think we've created a really major entertainment precinct in Melbourne," Williams said at the opening.
But church and welfare leaders have attacked the project, concerned that gambling is tearing at the fabric of Victoria state's conservative community.
Crown won Victoria's exclusive casino licence in September 1993 and has operated a temporary casino since June 1994.
Victorians are the country's biggest gamblers, though five years ago they were Australia's most timid punters. One in every 30 dollars earned by Victorians is now spent on gambling.
Gambling fever has also taken hold across the country. Australia now has 14 casinos dotted around the continent.
But moral crusaders are not alone in criticising this trend.
Major business groups like retailers, and even media baron Rupert Murdoch, have said that money once spent on consumer goods and newspapers is now fed into the gambling industry.
Sceptics in the financial markets have nicknamed the new complex the "Spruce Goose", after the U.S. 1940s seaplane which was too big to fly.
Even the casino's backers have expressed doubts about the project's mammoth size.
"This great city has a great image and we don't want it to be seen as 'Casino City'," Melbourne mayor Ivan Deveson said on Thursday. He said he did not want any more gambling projects.
The casino has 2,500 slot machines and 350 gaming tables.
Victoria state Premier Jeff Kennett, whose government has become increasingly reliant on gambling taxes, officially opened the casino.
One notable absentee from the opening was Australian Prime Minister, John Howard.
Howard has voiced concerns about the impact of gambling on the poor and on small businesses and says he believes gambling has reached saturation point.
Apart from gaming tables, the complex houses Australia's largest hotel, a convention centre, a cinema complex, 52 bars and restaurants and 34 upmarket retailers.
